statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Tigers snap 13-game skid against Terps
article.linkText: Clemson beats Maryland for first time since '97
article.story: CLEMSON, S.C. (AP) -- Sharrod Ford felt he couldn't be stopped. And for the first time in a long while against Maryland, neither could Clemson. Ford tied his career high with 25 points and the Tigers ended a 13-game losing streak against Maryland (No. 24 ESPN/USA Today; No. 22 AP) with an 88-73 victory on Tuesday night. "I was just everywhere. I had a lot of energy. I was just doing it all," Ford said with a smile. "I felt it tonight." Ford's play lifted the Tigers (11-10, 2-7 Atlantic Coast Conference) to their first win over Maryland since a 78-65 overtime victory at Littlejohn Coliseum on Dec. 4, 1997. That streak of futility figured to continue with Maryland back in the Top 25 after victories over Duke and Georgia Tech last week. But the Terrapins (13-6, 4-4) dealt with the fatigue of its Sunday night win over Georgia Tech and a Monday night plane trip to Clemson. "You don't have time to practice like you have to practice, but that shouldn't mean anything effort-wise," Maryland coach Gary Williams said. "You might not be perfect in what you do, but you should play harder than that." The Terps were cold from the start and stayed that way. They fell behind 13-2 and, after briefly moving in front 23-22 midway through the opening half, missed their final 13 shots of the half to fall behind 45-29. Could Maryland's long history of Clemson success led to a letdown? "You might say we didn't come as mentally ready as we should have," said John Gilchrist, who led Maryland with 18 points. "But in my opinion, I didn't think we overlooked them. I always knew we had challenges against Clemson. And tonight, they just really wanted it, you could tell." Ford said the players talked at halftime about holding the lead. The Tigers, who had lost five straight and seven of eight, didn't let up. Ford scored nine points during the Tigers' run to close the first half, then made four straight inside baskets as Clemson pushed the lead to 62-42. Maryland never got closer than 15 points the rest of the way. "I knew coming out we gave them confidence," Gilchrist said, "and it was going to be a long night." Nothing the Terps did worked. Forwards Travis Garrison and Ekene Ibekwe, who average just under 20 points and 14 rebounds combined, both ran into foul problems trying to stop Ford. They managed only 10 points and six boards before each fouled out early in the second half. Nik Caner-Medley, Maryland's leading scorer coming in, never found his rhythm, going 4-of-14 from the field (1-of-6 on 3s) and had nine points All Williams could do was stomp, scream and watch as Clemson finished with its most points in an ACC game this season. "Ford killed us," he said. "We couldn't stop him." When it was over, Clemson fans rushed the court and danced on the tiger paw logo to celebrate. "There is no question that our defense and rebounding were ahead of everything tonight," Clemson coach Oliver Purnell said. Ford's layup with 7:21 to go tied his best-ever output, set against Wofford last season. He also added 10 rebounds, his third straight double-double. Ford, a senior, had two blocks and two steals. Shawan Robinson had five of Clemson's seven 3-pointers and ended with 22 points. Freshman Sam Perry, who made his first start of the season, had a career-high 14 points for the Tigers. Ford said the way Clemson played against Maryland, don't count the Tigers out of the postseason just yet. "We lost a couple of games, we let some slip by but we're definitely not out of it," Ford said. "We just got to keep our heads."
